Acknowledging that you are playing your "hang up" game. The way this goes is we have something important and urgent, you hang up and refuse to
address so you can then send a call log to show I am trying to discuss the issue.
I am asking that we treat AD's threats of self-harm seriously enough to discuss while we still have context. Especially given that your only response is
"I'll monitor." Please reconsider your refusal to work with me on our child's mental health.
I'll note that this is important because Kari seemed quite surprised to hear about your decision to cut off contact with me last time because of a single
comment in "one session in". So I'm not sure you are making the right decisions here.
Please consider acting more urgently and working with me on decisions of this magnitude, given your history on much less urgent issues.

Message 2499 of 4024
This is a two-way street.
I am not going to make personal comments or assessments; you have my promise. I also hope you will strike a more constructive tone, like not starting
the call with negative comments.
I think we both need to be better and rally for the kids in mental health in this case. I honestly think we need help but you refuse to do that. But let's
at least have the discussion on AD.
I read you notes from the research I have done on Gifted Kids in this situation. I have a unique POV you don't from that, and I am trying to share and
educate you on AD's special needs.
Please call when it is good for you tonight..
Sent:04/15/2024 at 08:37 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 04/16/2024 at 12:36 AM)
Subject:Re: Can we debrief?
Message 2500 of 4024
Ok. I tried calling again, but you still won't pick up. Assuming you are trying to scoreboard for Annalisa instead of making an effort for Adrain.
Given the situation and the context I am providing, I hoped you cared enough or realized that you are not trained in children's mental health issues
well enough (especially of this magnitude). But it does not seem like you do either.
My issue is you have seized 100% control of the kids. You are their only input, and they are rapidly declining on your watch. Executing "your plan"
despite the guidance of multiple mental health professionals does not appear to be going great. We went from best buds with me as the primary
caregiver to thoughts of self-harm on your watch. I'll share a few examples I have seen.
You can dispute that you have something to do with this, but you can not dispute I have offered multiple times to pursue a more peaceful,
harmonious, child-focused alternative. You probably should also concede that you have refused those offers every time out of hand. If neither trained
professionals or my offers for a more peaceful route can get through, I am at a loss with you.
Please let me know if you will reconsider.

I'll also note by killing the reservations this year (after you killed October), I fear you have pushed any opportunities past where I might be employed
if I can get a job, and I can't really use them.
You are a whiz at this. The best I have ever seen tbh. None of this would come as a surprise to you so I assume it was all intentional. I don't get that.
It's much more work to screw me, right?
Message 2505 of 4024
"Then there is also the reality of situations that arrive on the fly like Elsa this AM. At this point, the fact that she blames me for her entire childhood
and you were just a bystander may be a deal breaker for her and I. Historically we spoke with one voice. Hell, I think July 5th came to a head because I
was defending you. But it's a big deal that may mean we don't talk again for years. We are quite literally crashing and burning. "
So, we noted a couple of months back that you had been lying to me about Elsa. You said she was unaware of our situation (even while we did the
beach move), but it turns out you had been backchanneling with her for weeks then.
When she exploded on me based solely on your perspective, it was a sad and painful unraveling of my time as her father since I met you two or three
decades ago. Just like your plans to divorce, your plan to eliminate my kids hit hard.
As I try to figure out how to either undo the story you tell as the single truth, or at least share things that actually made up our life in all its fullness, I
want to know what you are doing with her now so I can address your collusion with her.
We have tens of emails documenting lies about what you were doing, so I am asking you to be honest about what is going on now. She's had no
contact for months, so I assume all is going according to your plan for all 3 kids at this point.
So before I reach out can you give me an honest update of what you are doing with her and if I am not asking the "exact right question" what you have
already done? I don't need a recap of the previous lies. I know those. Just an update.
thanks!
Sent:04/16/2024 at 01:02 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 04/16/2024 at 02:34 PM)
Subject:Re: Communication
Message 2506 of 4024
We agreed to talk at 3:15, but you picked up long enough to refuse. You said that you were too busy and that you and Kari were addressing my
absence from participation.
I am asking again, for the second day in a row, to speak about Adrian's mental health and thoughts of self-harm so we can address this as his parents. I
have feedback to consider.
I am not saying it is right. But I am saying I talked with Kari, too, and I have done a lot of research into the way gifted children respond to these
Sent:04/16/2024 at 03:44 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 04/16/2024 at 04:48 PM)
Subject:Re: Can we debrief?

situations. I just want feedback.
There is no guidance that says that one parent should demand a child adopt their narrative of their past as a healthy path forward. This all happened
on your watch, your plan.
Please let me know when we can have the discussion. It is super important to me.
Message 2507 of 4024
So... I am super bummed that I have to send this to you instead of discussing it because after agreeing to talk about the situation with me again, you
refuse to. You said his spiral into self-destruction is entirely my fault. And I am the sole reason Adrian is having problems. I asked that we peacefully
and constructively discuss things we could consider as his parents.
But again, you have insisted on unilateral control as the single Omnipotent ruler of the Moyer family. I have sent similar proposals to this for months,
starting in September. I can re-send if you like. I have asked repeatedly to have you consider a healthier path forward that allows the kids to develop
their own opinions and be able to love us both.
You always say no. Your way is the only way. Period. And here we are. You won't consider what I wanted to share below. That seems nuts to me. So,
as you eliminated every memory from our house so there is no trace of their documented childhood, you also insist on your history only. I also
wonder if you will rewrite who you brought to breakfast with them at Harry's as well...?
-------------------------------- The Thoughts on Adrian I Wanted to Share --------------------------------
Christine-
I realize there is hurt on both sides, but our priority in our conversation should be finding common ground to benefit Adrian's mental and emotional
well-being. I want to stop scoreboarding and focus on establishing a unified front for Adrian’s sake. should reflect on how our actions and conflicts
are affecting Adrian. He's not just an observer; he's in the heart of this, and it's taking a toll on him. He has said repeatedly that he feels like he is in the
middle, which is an accurate statement.
And gifted children like Adrian can be more susceptible to our parental tension, leading to serious issues, like the self-harm he's already expressing.
Instead of focusing on our disputes, let’s concentrate on reinforcing positive parenting. Each of us should build him up, provide stability, and show
him unconditional love. Let's find a way to co-parent cooperatively, even if we need a mediator or a counselor to assist us. We don't have to be friends,
but we do need to be partners in parenting. We owe that to him right now.
- Establishing a Unified Front
Empathy and Acknowledgement- We’ve been through a lot, and our emotions have run high. It’s tough on both of us, and I see in real-time how it’s
affecting Adrian, given his unique emotional needs as a gifted child. We saw it again yesterday at Kari's.
The Impact of Conflict- Our conflict has been brutal on Adrian. He’s shown signs of emotional distress, and I know you’ve noticed changes in him as
well. As his parents, we both want what’s best for him; he needs us to work together right now.
The Need for Consistency and Truth- Gifted children like Adrian need a consistent and stable environment. They're more affected by discrepancies
and uncertainties. Conflicting stories or hidden truths will cause him more significant anxiety and confusion.
Child's Right to Love Both Parents- We both love Adrian, and he has the right to love both of us without feeling guilty or torn. When we use him as a
pawn, we're infringing on this right and putting our needs above his. Let's please stop that.
Sent:04/16/2024 at 04:20 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 04/16/2024 at 04:48 PM)
Subject:Re: Can we debrief?

- Parental Alienation and Its Impacts
Our Role as Parents- Adrian needs to see despite our differences, we both prioritize his well-being. Using him as a messenger or expecting him to take
sides places an unfair emotional burden on him. We need to protect him from our adult conflicts.
Adrian’s Well-being- We’ve both been his pillars in his 12 short years and must continue to be regardless of our acrimony. It hurts me deeply to see
him struggle like this. Parental alienation can be incredibly damaging, and it's taking a toll on him.
Rebuilding Trust- I want to rebuild trust with Adrian, not just for my sake but also for his mental and emotional health. As his father, we both have
to assure him that he is safe with me and doesn’t need to choose you over me or take your side.
Alienation for Gifted Children- Kari, who understands his advanced emotional and intellectual capacities, has expressed concern about our current
dynamic. Adrian's heightened sensitivity can magnify the emotional pain of feeling torn between us.
- Positive Memories and Their Role in Adrian’s Stability
Our Positive History- Adrian's memories of us as a family and our past experiences are his identity. Today he looks around and doesn't see any
representation of memories. You took those from him and he may feel like he's lost part of himself.
Both of Us are Adrian’s Life- Even though we’re separating, for Adrian’s psychological well-being, he needs to know we both love him and that he
hasn’t lost the love of either of us. He needs a sense of continuity and security to feel safe again.
Unified Communication- Let’s decide on how we’ll communicate with Adrian about the divorce and any changes in our household. It's 9 months
overdue so it's crucial we do it calmly and without casting blame to avoid causing him further distress.
Coping Mechanisms—We should consider strategies to help Adrian cope with the changes. Perhaps we can work with Kari to develop a consistent
narrative that helps him understand the situation in an honest but also reassuring way togehter.
- Setting a Path Forward
Long-Term Consequences- The long-term psychological effects of being in the middle can be profound for a child as perceptive as Adrian. If we
continue this way, he might struggle with trust, relationship-building, and self-worth in the future.
Immediate Actions- Until Conner is done, we should work on creating a peaceful environment around Adrian. This means resolving not to fight in
front of him and to ensure he feels supported by both of us during his time with either parent.
Long-term Considerations- We need to find a way to co-parent effectively. This is not just about us but about ensuring Adrian’s giftedness is not
overshadowed by familial turmoil. He deserves to have a fulfilling childhood and reach his potential.
Collaboration with Professionals—I want us to take the advice of the professionals seriously, not cherry-pick. They have Adrian’s best interests at
heart. Let’s collaborate and utilize their expertise to support Adrian through this crazy mess he is in.
Let's both remember the positive role each of us has played in Adrian's life and figure out how we can continue contributing to his development and
happiness by creating a stable and nurturing environment for Adrian moving forward. Thanks in advance for your partnership and thoughtful
consideration...
-robert

Message 2508 of 4024
Writing something does not make it true.
You can send something like this, but actions are what matter.
After stating how we should communicate and no snarky comments etc, see three OFW unrelated to this sent earlier during my work day and snarky
comments included below.
Sent:04/16/2024 at 04:55 PM
From:Christine Moyer
To:Robert Moyer (First Viewed: 04/16/2024 at 04:56 PM)
Subject:Re: Can we debrief?
Message 2509 of 4024
The other messages were not related to this. Period. We have a ton of outstanding issues that have never been addressed. You won't let me. If we can
do "running list" again it solves that.
Per this, I asked to discuss this with you over the course of two days, multiple times, while it was fresh. You said you're the only one who will make
decisions and "monitor." That was it.
I have presented a detailed plan for us to discuss below, just as I promised I would. I did the research and took the time to help Adrian. He is my son,
and I want the best for him
You can make any excuse you want for not partnering on his mental health. I have done this since September. This is not an outlier. You always reject
what I say out of hand. Always.
Here are just a couple more examples of my attempts to work with you. Both flatly refused by you. You would not even consider what I think is
healthy and supportive support for them.
So, I agree that writing it does not make it true. What makes it true is the digital paper trail of my attempts to work with you to help our kids and then
your documented refusals to do so.
You can pretend you entertained my perspective, just like you pretended to trust Dr Brown or even Kari now. The actual chronology will show
something different. It's all documented.
- June 30th: The best the Moyers ever were as a Family Together
- July 4th: You hid the affair with Kevin by moving off Sbux servers
- July 5th: You asked for a peaceful separation and nesting for us
- July 23rd: You lied about you and Kevin but I showed you proof
- April 16th: Max won't even talk to me, AD is thinking of Self Harm
- April 17th: You're refusing to engage on my thoughts for AD
I can add more details, but instead, I would like to discuss what I have proposed. I assure you I'll be kind and constructive. I hope you reconsider and
Sent:04/16/2024 at 05:38 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 04/16/2024 at 06:41 PM)
Subject:Re: Can we debrief?

work with me in Adrian's best interest.
Please give it some thought, Christine. We need to figure out how to work together or we are really going to screw our kids up. The retribution is
going too far. I am here, just let me know..
-robert
Message 2510 of 4024
So, you always said I manipulated you in our last Instgram pic at Tumblecreek.
You said you refused to smile but that I had made you do it for one pic that day.
Specifically, I finally browbeat you into smiling against your will for the last one.
I don't think that is what is reflected in our photo roll. It looks like you smiled for all eight of them in a row in fact. Take a look for yourself. You were
all smiles in every pic that I see.
You may not remember things about us accurately. You might be recasting your memory around what you want to believe rather than what really
happened. Do you see any frowns?
I do want to point out that we did amazing for the kids on that camping trip. Despite what we uncovered (and I had some rough moments), we
showed we could act in their best interest.
Let's try again... for them?

------------------------------------------------------------------------ My Plan Subject to Kari's Advice
Building a solid foundation for mending and strengthening my relationship with Adrian is essential. I will stay healthy and move forward one step at a
time. I will maintain my sobriety and be transparent with him when he has questions. This includes safe words, Soberlink, or anything else that gives
him peace of mind. This will take time, but it's the long game I'm playing.
After my discussion with Kari, talking with my sponsor, and doing my research, my proposed focus will be:
•     Apologize. I'm sorry today, but I will keep apologizing for what I have done. I want Adrian to know I mean it and hear what he says.
•     I need to be open and transparent about my recovery so Adrian understands how serious I am about staying sober so that I will be there for
him.
•     When he opens up, I will listen first. I want him to express himself fully before I respond to show him that he is valued and his voice matters to
me.
•     Given that actions speak louder than words and consistency is essential, I will continue to show up, stay sober, and keep a regular routine.
•     I will work with Kari to set clear goals for my time with Adrian. It can be either about doing activities or just heartfelt chats. But we need the
time.
Sent:04/20/2024 at 08:40 PM
From:Robert Moyer
To:Christine Moyer (First Viewed: 04/21/2024 at 05:06 PM)
Subject:Re: Adrian... two weeks in a row
Attachments:Recommendations_for_Gifted_Children-_AD.pdf (891 KB)

•     Adrian needs to have a say in what we do when we spend time together so he feels respected and in charge. I want him to feel his sense of
control.
•     We've bonded through sports, but I would also like to continue to bond with him intellectually, so I'll suggest activities that challenge him
mentally.
•     I want to demonstrate my agape love for him so he sees that it is unconditional and not dependent on anything Adrain does, says, or achieves.
•     My therapy will be essential to ensure I am strong mentally and physically so I can focus on Adrian rather than what has transpired with us
since July.
•     It will take my time. Rebuilding trust requires that, but I also need the opportunity to do it so we can celebrate small victories and stay the
course.
Naturally, I am all ears if you have any input on this plan for me. That is, after all, why I want to discuss it with you. Having two parents working
together in his best interest is far more beneficial than us operating without communication, checkpoints, goals, or shared strategies for his mental
health. So, please reconsider the position you've taken since Hong Kong.
----------------------------------------------------------------------  My Suggestion to You as a Co-parent
If you really want to help Adrian navigate through everything we have him messed up with, here are my suggested steps that you could take to make
things better genuinely:
•     We need co-parenting therapy. We have to stop making excuses and figure out how to work together for Adrian's sake. This is about him.
•     I hope you'll show empathy and take a moment to understand how much this affects him and act. He feels like he is then in the middle now.
•     I'd like you to encourage Adrian to share his feelings for both of us neutrally so that he doesn't feel like he has to take sides to please one of us.
•     The internet and attorneys are your best resources, said no professional child therapist ever. Please consider taking the advice of professionals.
•     I need you to start supporting his relationship with me. Cutting off contact and requiring supervised visits further villainizes me and fosters
distrust.
•     I want to stop the blame game. He sees this, and it's not healthy. We need to quit being hospital to one another when he is around. That is
devastating.
•     SAAS was a big decision we made together. Let's find other opportunities to show him that we will put him first and make decisions in his
best interest.
•     I would encourage you to do more reading. I appreciate your focus on self-care, but understanding the impact of divorce might help you
better support him.
•     You might consider what we are teaching him about forgiveness. This is an important lesson in Adrian's life, teaching him how to handle hard
situations.
•     I support your therapy, so you are there and healthy for him, and also after some healthy introspection on the messages we send, admitting
mistakes.
Focusing on these steps could make a massive difference in Adrian's life. He needs both of his parents to be at their best and work together, especially
now. It's up to you to consider or not.
I'll continue to do this whether you get on board or not. But it's important to me to continue to try and get you involved for Adrian's sake.
-robert
